Hi All - Looking for advice on how to best approach a problem.  Building a website with a 'Product Catalog' feature for about 15 products.   Each product will have it's own website page.  I'm developing a template for the page.  On the product page the product features are listed in a table.   Two questions:  1)  What is the best way to add the table data onto each page without having to type out all the table row data such as 'product weight'?  (i.e.  copy and paste)    2)  How can I 'templateize' the table so that if I update the width of the table, it will be updated across all 15 product pages?     Any tips would be greatly appreciated.  ps. The client does not have CMS has part of their subscription.
You could do this pretty easily with dynamic pages <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/data/dynamic-pages>
And build out a HubDB for your product pages
<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/data/dynamic-pages#hubdb-dynamic-pages>
<@U01QVR44MEY> sorry I added at the end that the customer doesn't have a subscription to the CMS.   They just have the marketing subscription.
<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/guides/dynamic-pages/hubdb>
oh got it
And you want to pull the data from the HubSpot products
Thank you for the reply!
<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/api/crm/products>
<@U01QVR44MEY> No, the data could be hard coded.
oh I'm confused then why are you building a template? and is this a HubSpot template?
<@U01QVR44MEY> yes, it's a HubSpot website page template.   It has sections. One of the sections will be a 'product features' section like 'size', 'weight', 'price', etc.

<@U01QVR44MEY> I am consdiering creating a module for the table and putting the table data into a text field as JSON, and then using Javascript to create the table  <tr><td>... rows of data.  But that feels hacky and I'm wondering if there's a better way to do it without using CMS or HubDb which is beyond the budget for this client.
These products are very static.  they never change.  I couldn't justify using a CMS or HubDb.

When I’ve had similar issues in the past and HubDB wasn’t available, I’d look to see if the free tier of AirTable fit the use-case and just used that as a substitute. Obviously it means you can’t use HubL, but that’s part of the compromise of not using HS’s built-in tools.
If using that data in a module, you can also add a link for content editors in the help text to take them to the table for editing.

<@U26BLKGE4> thanks for your reply.  Is there any technical reason not to just save the data as JSON in a text field and generate the table rows using JavaScript in a custom 'product features' module?
Here is what the table will look like:

Depends on if you need a front-end editing experience for the website owners. I’ve also gone the route of building out data in HubL dicts within partial HTML files, then importing those dicts in modules or templates where they’re needed, but obviously you need to know JSON structure to edit the data in that case.

You suggested pasting the JSON in a module field previously, leading me to believe webpage editors needed some level of control. If that’s not the case, then absolutely JSON or a HubL dict would be a potential solution
<@U26BLKGE4> No. The owners do not need to edit the data.  It will never change or they will just get me to do it if it does.   I've never heard of HubL dict.  It sounds like a possible solution.
<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/hubl/variables-macros-syntax#import>

Yup, so you would just make a `products.html` or similar file with a `products` variable and then `{% import "..xxx.../products.html" as anyname %}` and access the data in HubL as `{{ anyname.products }}`.
<@U26BLKGE4> can I specify a different import file for every page/module instance?
<@U26BLKGE4> or do I put all the product data in products.html and use some logic to figure out which data to display?
either or
whatever makes the most sense
<@U26BLKGE4> ok thank you this is a big discovery for me!
Hey <@U6ZL2UZJ8> you should be able to do that by going to here as with this slack workspace, you have control of your own profile: <https://HubSpotdev.slack.com/account/settings#email>

Hello All, I am trying to create a tabbing system in-page, where each tab contains a set of modules as its associated content; a "flexible content container" or "nested module content" if you will. Any suggestions for approach? Is this do-able? I am a wordpress developer, working on a HubSpot build

could not find a relevant channel so I will ask it here

For one of our clients we need to send a webhook to an app which will trigger a Whatsapp flow/bot and send a message to the HS contact. Normally this is easily done by using the webhook address and setup a Workflow but this app handles webhooks through emails submissions :slightly_smiling_face: So we need to send a plain text email consisting of a JSON object.

We wanted to do this by sending it through an internal email notification, but since those emails are fulls with styling and a HS logo, the webhook is not working. Does anyone know a solution? Would it be possible to write a custom function inside a workflow and send the email like that?

Is there a way to create a ‘group meeting’ with users that don’t have a HubSpot account? We like HubSpot’s scheduling for intersecting availability, but we have some team members that have no need to take up a HubSpot paid seat, but need to be invited to the meetings like everyone else. (we use google meet).
So the <#C019VT42R8X|workflows> channel is a great place to post this. But yes you could use a custom coded action to send that data out to the webhook and format however you want to format it

From a UX perspective, this “Private Content” default screen should ABSOLUTELY have a link to the *sign-in page*. It’s a huge issue with users getting confused as to why they can’t log-in after they click on the wrong link because HubSpot sends 2 log-in related emails, one to register the email with a password, and then a confirmation email. It’s an absolutely nightmare and my analytics tell a story of users keep clicking on the registration link looking for ways to login to see the private content, and eventually they give up. Too much friction, too many emails for something that should be pretty simple - click a link, save the password, show the content.

Hello everyone. Does anyone know, in the UI, how to show a dynamic landing page as a Thank you. Use Case: Show a different calendar on the thanks page depending on the question answered on form on the landing page. I cannot make it work. User: fill out form, choose option A from a drop down, Thanks page Shows calendar for A. User chooses option B, they see the calendar for B. Help :slightly_smiling_face: If not in UI, can you give me some hints on where to put the code?

Hello HubSpot Nerds! We are a 501(c)(3) non-profit with $120K in-kind support from Catchafire, a great place to expand your portfolio and to find more clientele leads while getting credit for the charitable work you do. <https://gift.catchafire.org/organizations/assuaged-foundation--inc-_46259/>

I haven't be able to find any HubSpot expertise for a job that we posted, would love any help possible. Thank you so much!

Hi <@U02C45QBF8D>, we have been working on the near same functionality where we show different calendars based on different inputs by the user, you can put in multiple script embed codes in the page using javascript and embed them based on the condition if the input is "A" or "B".
